title: Augusta County: John Scott to Samuel Hunt, April 2, 1866
summary: In this informal report, John Scott begins by saying that his students have been progressing quite remarkably. He then complains about a black "Woman Preacher" in Staunton who had persuaded many citizens to leave the "Colored Methodist Ch." He says that the situation has threatened the financial integrity of the AMA's operations in Staunton. Scott mentions that he traveled to Lexington, Virginia, and gave a speech on "Free Labor and Its Reward," concluding that the schools in that town were doing very well. He also discusses boarding arrangements for teachers in Staunton.
keywords: African Americans, Education, Race Relations, Church/Religious Activity, Women, Economy, American Civil War
